results.title: Fidelio
results.brief_description: Glyndebourne Festival Opera 1979 production of Beethoven’s “Fidelio” with words by J.N. Bouilly, J.F. Sonnleithner and F. Treitschke, produced by Peter Hall with the London Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Bernard Haitink and the Glyndebourne Chorus. Set in a Spanish prison, the opera tells of a wife, Leonore (Elisabeth Soderstrom), who, disguised as a man (Fidelio), enters the prison to free her husband, the prisoner, Florestan (Anton de Ridder). Cast also includes Ian Caley (Jaquino), Elizabeth Gale (Marzelline), Curt Appelgren (Rocco), Robert Allman (Don Pizarro) and Michael Langdon (Don Fernando). Sung in German with English subtitles.

results.title: Fiddler on the roof
results.creator_credit: Norman Jewison, Mirisch Corporation and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: A marvellous film version of the Jerry Bock/Sheldon Harnick Broadway musical. It tells the story of an impoverished Russian-Jewish family headed by Tevye (played by Topol), the village milkman, and his wife, Golda. Their three eldest daughters seek husbands of their own choosing rather than those chosen by the village matchmaker. Then a cruel anti-Jewish pogrom forces the family to flee to America and start a new life. The musical was itself adapted from Shalom Aleichem’s story, “Tevye and his Daughters”.

results.title: Fiddle-de-dee = Fiddle de dee
results.creator_credit: Norman McLaren and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: With animation by Norman McLaren, this experimental film is described as a film fantasy of dancing music and dancing colour. It is an abstract interpretation in colour of the music “Listen to the Mocking Bird” played by an old time fiddler and recorded on the soundtrack. Norman McLaren, painting on film, translates sound into sight, resulting in colours rippling, flowing, flickering and blending along with the music. (Awards: Brussels; Rome; Salerno).

results.title: Fibrous plaster in Australia
results.creator_credit: John Kenyon, Gateway Film Productions and M K and M Pictures
results.brief_description: Shows the mining of gypsum in South Australia, calcining for plaster, harvesting of sisal in eastern Africa for fibre, manufacture of fibrous plaster sheets and forms, and their fixing and joining in modern building construction.

results.title: Fiberglass = Fibreglass
results.creator_credit: Helmut Engelhardt, Joe Hayward and Moreland-Latchford Productions
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the versatility of fibreglass, showing preparation of a single mould, lamination, removal of the mould and finishing. Also shows the method of repairing an object made of fibreglass.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Helmut Engelhardt, Joe Hayward and Moreland-Latchford Productions

results.title: Fiber in art = Fibre in art
results.creator_credit: Paul Burnford and Paul Burnford Film Productions
results.brief_description: Part of the “Materials in art” series. Shows the use of fibre in knotting, stitchery and weaving using a variety of simple looms. Demonstrates an array of techniques that can be used in the classroom. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: FI11 Pilots first flight
results.brief_description: Pilots and navigators trained to fly F111 aircraft, spend weeks mastering the process in a flight simulator and learning about the planes before becoming proficient enough to fly the F111 fighter jets. Trainee pilots become skilled in the performance of the F111 whilst the navigator trainees study the radar and navigation systems of the aircraft. This program documents the training process which results in the pilots and navigators first flight in the F111 jets.

results.title: Feverhouse
results.brief_description: Old and out of time, the monstrous architecture of the institution forms a world endlessly growing into corridors, courtyards, fire escapes, places of worship and discipline. Moving freely through the building, manipulating his puppets, is an unfeeling and intimidating force - thief who preys upon the inhabitants. The inmates and their world are completely inseparable. One inhabitant is a nurse, numbed and repressed by a place which, she knows, touches and disfigures everything it contains. She becomes obsessed with one of the inmates, a lost and blind archivist, impotent amongst his nightmare relics from ancient dead cultures. In a desperate attempt to form some perfect bond with him, she uses the thief as a go-between to lure him into a secret tryst.

results.title: Fever pitch
results.creator_credit: David Evans, Amanda Posey and Wildgaze Films
results.brief_description: Paul Ashworth discovers his passion for soccer when he accompanies his father to an Arsenal game. 24 years later, he still has the same passion, and is an unorthodox, deeply pessimistic thirty something English teacher. The highs and lows of Arsenal’s performance mirrors that in Paul’s personal life, thus the two worlds intermingle. Enter Sarah, and a relationship develops between two people that think the other one is either uptight or a soccer lout. As their relationship develops, Paul must question the distinction and importance between his personal life and his sporting fanaticism, as he is faced with the choice of deciding between following Arsenal’s first chance to win the championship in 18 years, or to pursue love. Cast includes Colin Firth, Ruth Gemmell, Neil Pearson and Lorraine Ashbourne. Based on the novel by Nick Hornby.

results.title: Feux follets
results.creator_credit: Jean-Claude Labrecque, Jacques Bobet and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Les Feux Follets (Will-‘o-the-Wisps) was founded as an amateur dance group in Montreal and developed into a professional group whose repertoire represents the folklore and the ethnic origins of the Canadian people. Two dances illustrate the group’s virtuosity - a Plains Indian Betrothal dance, and a more frenetic exhibition of the sixties “go-go” dancing. Choreographed by Michel Cartier; music Claude Poirier; sound by Ron Alexander, Roger Lamoureux, Bernie Bordeleau and photographed and edited by Jean-Claude Labrecque.
